dn34:1.2.1.pli: Eko, āvuso, dhammo bahukāro, eko dhammo bhāvetabbo, eko dhammo pariññeyyo, eko dhammo pahātabbo, eko dhammo hānabhāgiyo, eko dhammo visesabhāgiyo, eko dhammo duppaṭivijjho, eko dhammo uppādetabbo, eko dhammo abhiññeyyo, eko dhammo sacchikātabbo.
dn34:1.2.1.en: Reverends, one thing is helpful, one thing should be developed, one thing should be completely understood, one thing should be given up, one thing makes things worse, one thing leads to distinction, one thing is hard to comprehend, one thing should be produced, one thing should be directly known, one thing should be realized.

dn34:1.2.8.en: What one thing should be completely understood?

dn34:1.3.1.pli: Dve dhammā bahukārā, dve dhammā bhāvetabbā, dve dhammā pariññeyyā, dve dhammā pahātabbā, dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā, dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā, dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā, dve dhammā uppādetabbā, dve dhammā abhiññeyyā, dve dhammā sacchikātabbā.
dn34:1.3.1.en: Two things are helpful, two things should be developed, two things should be completely understood, two things should be given up, two things make things worse, two things lead to distinction, two things are hard to comprehend, two things should be produced, two things should be directly known, two things should be realized.

dn34:1.3.8.en: What two things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.4.9.en: What three things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.5.13.en: What four things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.6.15.en: What five things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.7.17.en: What six things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.8.10.en: What seven things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.1.34.en: What eight things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.2.9.en: What nine things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.3.1.pli: Dasa dhammā bahukārā …pe… dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā.
dn34:2.3.1.en: Ten things are helpful, ten things should be developed, ten things should be completely understood, ten things should be given up, ten things make things worse, ten things lead to distinction, ten things are hard to comprehend, ten things should be produced, ten things should be directly known, ten things should be realized.

dn34:2.3.48.en: What ten things should be completely understood?

sn56.29:1.5.pli: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṁ ariyasaccānaṁ atthi ariyasaccaṁ pariññeyyaṁ, atthi ariyasaccaṁ pahātabbaṁ, atthi ariyasaccaṁ sacchikātabbaṁ, atthi ariyasaccaṁ bhāvetabbaṁ.
sn56.29:1.5.en: Of these four noble truths, there is one to be completely understood, one to be given up, one to be realized, and one to be developed.

sn56.29:2.1.en: And which noble truth should be completely understood?

sn56.29:2.2.pli: Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasaccaṁ pariññeyyaṁ, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pahātabbaṁ, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ sacchikātabbaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ bhāvetabbaṁ.
sn56.29:2.2.en: The noble truth of suffering should be completely understood. The noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up. The noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized. The noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.

sn23.4:2.1.pli: “Pariññeyye ca, rādha, dhamme desessāmi pariññañca pariññātāviṁ puggalañca.
sn23.4:2.1.en: “Rādha, I will teach you the things that should be completely understood, complete understanding, and the person who has completely understood.

sn23.4:2.5.en: “And what things should be completely understood?

sn23.4:2.7.en: These are called the things that should be completely understood.

23. Complete Understanding

an4.254:1.3.en: There are things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

an4.254:2.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā?
an4.254:2.1.en: And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge?

an4.254:2.3.pli: ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā.
an4.254:2.3.en: These are called the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

sn45.159:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bhāvento ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ bahulīkaronto ye dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā, te dhamme abhiññā parijānāti …pe…
sn45.159:1.2.en: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path completely understands by direct knowledge the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

sn45.159:2.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā abhiññā pariññeyyā?
sn45.159:2.1.en: And what are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge?

sn45.159:2.5.en: These are the things that should be completely understood by direct knowledge.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 45
12. Hard Work
159. A Guest House

an6.61:3.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (1)
an6.61:3.5.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

an6.61:8.4.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (6)
an6.61:8.4.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

an6.61:12.6.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
an6.61:12.6.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

sn56.12:1.3.en: ‘This noble truth of suffering has been completely understood.’ …

mn43:6.4.pli: imesaṁ dhammānaṁ saṁsaṭṭhānaṁ no visaṁsaṭṭhānaṁ paññā bhāvetabbā, viññāṇaṁ pariññeyyaṁ.
mn43:6.4.en: “The difference between these things is that wisdom should be developed, while consciousness should be completely understood.”
